text: Are you sure it's solicitation for jobs or is it solicitation for purchasing services/goods? Either way it doesn't make sense because they are trying to control what an outside party does. When I was in-house I just bought my employee handbook concerns up to my manager during a one-on-one to ask for further clarification. It seems like this rule is written in a way that's unenforceable because you cannot control what other people do and it would be hard to go after someone outside the company (although not impossible.)

text:
I would also recommend looking for companies that already create content similar to what you write. Connect with the leaders/decision makers there on LinkedIn, and start some conversations. 

Even if they don’t need content right away, this will help you build a relevant network.

text: <@U028781SL6P> I think this pertains to soliciting your fellow coworkers for a job. So like, if you run a startup on the side or in the near future (usually they give a length of time that you can’t solicit)… you can’t ask your coworkers to jump ship and join you.

elements.text: I think this pertains to soliciting your fellow coworkers for a job. So like, if you run a startup on the side or in the near future (usually they give a length of time that you can’t solicit)… you can’t ask your coworkers to jump ship and join you.

text: Oh but also… it might just be like, “Don’t ask your coworkers to buy girl scout cookies.” And for that… I say that makes sense. It distracts from work.

text:
*Deep breath* All right, here goes…
*Am I the only one concerned about WFH and networking?*
For context: I’m 26 and in year 3 of my content career. I’ve done stints both at an agency and in-house (a small firm) and am starting in on bigger freelance contracts. All remote, WFH roles.
The problem: I feel like I’m struggling to (meaningfully) expand my network.
I guess what’s bothering me is I feel like I’m relying on social media (LinkedIn and Twitter) to patch over a big ol’ networking-sized hole in my career development.
Anyone feel the same/have any advice?
(Also, if you’re in content and want to connect on any of the aforementioned platforms, comment on the thread or shoot me a DM!) Thanks!

elements.text: Deep breath

The problem: I feel like I’m struggling to (meaningfully) expand my network.
I guess what’s bothering me is I feel like I’m relying on social media (LinkedIn and Twitter) to patch over a big ol’ networking-sized hole in my career development.
Anyone feel the same/have any advice?
(Also, if you’re in content and want to connect on any of the aforementioned platforms, comment on the thread or shoot me a DM!) Thanks!

text: LinkedIn and Twitter are great for networking. If you feel like you are relying too heavily on social media, make a goal for yourself to have networking chats with people in the industry. Many content peeps are more than happy to take thirty minutes to have a conversation and exchange ideas. Give yourself a small goal of one chat a week or a few chats a month.

text: Hey Spencer, I have an awesome WFH setup but still visit a local coworking space every month or so. I find it helps to just get out of the house and meet people face to face. I go there purely for the networking aspect; even though I get less work done on those days there's still a ton of value in it.

text:
Yeah, I'd say working in an office held back my marketing networking :slightly_smiling_face:

Now that everyone's WFH, it's way easier to connect with people all over the place. Just ask people for a coffee chat and they'll most likely say yes!

text: The fact that there are at least 3 different interpretations of the clause in this brief thread alone demonstrates how it’s not a well-written policy.

text: How can anyone follow it if they don’t know what it means?

text: I used to lead NerdWallet’s content team and we hired a number of career freelancers who decided for various reasons that a f/t job better fit their needs, at least during that stage in their lives. What made it work well for various folks: Our jobs could be done remotely (since I started our team in 2013); we offered a lot of autonomy and scheduling flex; and we offered a lot of training and development. Work-life balance was good. And we let people freelance on the side as long as it wasn't competitive and it didn't involve politics or such that would blow back on the company and drag us into crap.

elements.text: I used to lead NerdWallet’s content team and we hired a number of career freelancers who decided for various reasons that a f/t job better fit their needs, at least during that stage in their lives. What made it work well for various folks: Our jobs could be done remotely (since I started our team in 2013); we offered a lot of autonomy and scheduling flex; and we offered a lot of training and development. Work-life balance was good. And we let people freelance on the side as long as it wasn't competitive and it didn't involve politics or such that would blow back on the company and drag us into crap.

text: And FWIW, people loved our culture and tended to stick with the company for long tenures. We had low voluntary turnover on our content team. That team is now at about 120 writers and editors.

elements.text: And FWIW, people loved our culture and tended to stick with the company for long tenures. We had low voluntary turnover on our content team. That team is now at about 120 writers and editors.
